dialogs.original: Why looks your grace so heavily today?
dialogs.translated: Why do you look so sad today, your Grace?

dialogs.original: O, I have passed a miserable night,    So full of ugly dreams, of ugly sights,    That, as I am a Christian faithful man,    I would not spend another such a night    Though twere to buy a world of happy days,    So full of dismal terror was the time.
dialogs.translated: Oh, I had a miserable night last night. It was so full of ugly dreams and terrifying visions that I swear I wouldn't choose to spend another night like iteven if it bought me a lifetime of happy days.

dialogs.original: What was your dream, my lord? I pray you tell me.
dialogs.translated: What was your dream, my lord? Please tell me.

dialogs.original: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower    And was embarked to cross to Burgundy,    And in my company my brother Gloucester,    Who from my cabin tempted me to walk    Upon the hatches.   Thence we looked toward England    And cited up a thousand fearful times,    During the wars of York and Lancaster    That had befall'n us.   As we paced along    Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,    Methought that Gloucester stumbled, and in falling    Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard    Into the tumbling billows of the main.    O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown,    What dreadful noise of waters in my ears,    What sights of ugly death within my eyes.    Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks,    Ten thousand men that fishes gnawed upon,    Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,    Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,    All scattered in the bottom of the sea.    Some lay in dead men's skulls, and in the holes    Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept    as 'twere in scorn of eyes   reflecting gems,    That wooed the slimy bottom of the deep    And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.
dialogs.translated: I dreamed that I had broken out of the Tower and was on a ship to France, and my brother Richard was with me. He persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on the boat's deck with him. From there we looked toward England and reminisced about our many frightening experiences during the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters. As we paced along the boards of the deck, Richard seemed to stumble, and as I tried to grab him he knocked me overboard into the rolling waves. Oh Lord, how painful it was to drownwith the dreadful noise of water in my ears and the ugly visions of death in my eyes. I seemed to see a thousand shipwrecks; ten thousand men whose bodies had been gnawed by fish; bars of gold; huge anchors; heaps of pearls; and vast amounts of priceless jewels, all scattered on the bottom of the sea. Some of the jewels lay inside of dead men's skulls. And they had crept into their empty eye socketsso that they looked like false eyes. The gems reflected the slimy bottom of the ocean floor, and mocked the dead bones that lay scattered around.

dialogs.original: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
dialogs.translated: Did you really have so much time to examine the secrets of the deep while you were dying?

dialogs.original: Methought I had, and often did I strive    To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood    Stopped in my soul   and would not let it forth    To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air,    But smothered it within my panting bulk,    Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.
dialogs.translated: It seemed like I did. And I often tried to die, but the jealous waves kept my soul bottled up inside of me, and wouldn't let it go free to find the empty, wandering air. The water kept my soul smothered inside my panting body until I almost burst open.

dialogs.original: Awaked you not in this sore agony?
dialogs.translated: Didn't you wake up during all this agony?

dialogs.original: No, no, my dream was lengthened after life.    O, then began the tempest to my soul.    I passed, methought, the melancholy flood,    With that sour ferryman which poets write of,    Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.    The first that there did greet my stranger-soul    Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick,    Who cried aloud, What scourge for perjury    Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?    And so he vanished. Then came wand'ring by    A shadow like an angel, with bright hair    Dabbled in blood,   and he shrieked out aloud    "Clarence is comefalse, fleeting, perjured Clarence,    That stabbed me in the field by Tewkesbury.    Seize on him, furies. Take him unto torment."    With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends    Environed me and howled in mine ears    Such hideous cries that with the very noise    I trembling waked,   and for a season after    Could not believe but that I was in hell,    Such terrible impression made my dream.
dialogs.translated: No, no, my dream continued after I died. Oh, then the real storm of my soul began! I passed over the river of death with the help of Charon, the ferryman of the underworld, and I entered the kingdom of perpetual night. The first soul to greet me there was my great father-in-law, the Earl of Warwick, who cried aloud, "What terrible punishment for oath-breaking can this dark kingdom inflict on that false Clarence?" And then he vanished. Next a shadow like an angel came wandering by, with its bright hair spattered with blood, and it shrieked aloud, "Clarence is herefalse, fickle, lying Clarence, who stabbed me in the field at Tewkesbury. Seize him, avenging devils. Take him and torture him." With that it seemed like a legion of foul demons surrounded me and howled in my ears, and their cries were so loud and horrible that I woke up trembling. And for a long time afterward I still believed that I was in hellthat was how terrible an impression this dream made on me.

dialogs.original: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you. I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
dialogs.translated: It's no surprise that it frightened you, my lord. I'm afraid just hearing you tell it.

dialogs.original: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things,    That now give evidence against my soul,    For Edwards sake, and see how he requites me.    O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease thee,    But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds,    Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!    O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!    Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.    My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
dialogs.translated: [To BRAKENBURY] Ah, jailer, jailer, I did all those things that the ghosts accused me ofand my crimes are now giving evidence against my soul. I did them all for King Edward's sake, and now see how he thanks me.

dialogs.original: I will, my lord. God give your Grace good rest.
dialogs.translated: I will, my lord. May God give you good rest.

dialogs.original: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,    Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.    Princes have but their titles for their glories,    An outward honor for an inward toil,    And, for unfelt imaginations,    They often feel a world of restless cares,    So that betwixt their titles and low name    There's nothing differs but the outward fame.
dialogs.translated: Sorrow breaks natural rhythms and interrupts sleep, making night into morning and noon into night. The only glory princes really have are their titles, which are outward honors for their inner troubles. They experience a world of worry about imaginary things, so that the only real difference between princes and peasants is the princes' outward fame.

dialogs.original: Ho, whos here?
dialogs.translated: Hey, who's there?

dialogs.original: What wouldst thou, fellow? And how camst thou hither?
dialogs.translated: What do you want, man? And how did you get here?

dialogs.original: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.
dialogs.translated: I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.

dialogs.original: What, so brief?
dialogs.translated: What, do you dare to be so blunt with me?

dialogs.original: 'Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.Let him seeour commission, and talk no more.
dialogs.translated: It's better to be blunt than to be long-winded, sir.

dialogs.original: I am in this commanded to deliver    The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.    I will not reason what is meant hereby    Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.    There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.     [He hands them the keys]     Ill to the king and signify to him    That thus I have resigned my charge to you.
dialogs.translated: This warrant commands me to deliver the noble Duke of Clarence into your hands. I won't ask what this means, for I'd rather not know about something that might make me guilty later. There's the duke, sleeping, and here are the keys. [He hands them the keys] I'll go to the king and tell him that I've handed over my prisoner to you.

dialogs.original: You may, sir. 'Tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.
dialogs.translated: You may do that, sir. It's a wise idea. Farewell.

dialogs.original: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?
dialogs.translated: Well, should I stab him as he sleeps?

dialogs.original: No. Hell say twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
dialogs.translated: No. When he wakes up he'll say that we killed him like cowards.

dialogs.original: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
dialogs.translated: Why, he won't be waking up until Judgment Day.

dialogs.original: Why, then hell say we stabbed him sleeping.
dialogs.translated: Well, then on Judgment Day he'll say that we stabbed him in his sleep.

dialogs.original: The urging of that word judgment hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
dialogs.translated: That word "judgment" has made me feel a little bit guilty.

dialogs.original: What, art thou afraid?
dialogs.translated: What, are you afraid?

dialogs.original: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
dialogs.translated: Not afraid to kill him, since we have a warrant for it. But I'm afraid to be damned for killing him. No warrant can protect me from that.

dialogs.original: I thought thou hadst been resolute.
dialogs.translated: I thought you were sure about this.

dialogs.original: So I amto let him live.
dialogs.translated: I am surethat we should let him live.

dialogs.original: Ill back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
dialogs.translated: I'll go back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

dialogs.original: Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humor of mine will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.
dialogs.translated: No, please, stay a minute. I'm hoping that my compassionate mood will pass. It usually only lasts about twenty seconds.

dialogs.original: How dost thou feel thyself now?
dialogs.translated: How are you feeling now?

dialogs.original: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
dialogs.translated: Honestly, my conscience is still troubling me a bit.

dialogs.original: Remember our reward when the deeds done.
dialogs.translated: Remember the reward we'll get when the deed is done.

dialogs.original: Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.
dialogs.translated: By God, he must die! I had forgotten about the reward.

dialogs.original: Wheres thy conscience now?
dialogs.translated: Where's your conscience now?

dialogs.original: O, in the duke of Gloucesters purse.
dialogs.translated: Oh, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

dialogs.original: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
dialogs.translated: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, your conscience will fly out.

dialogs.original: 'Tis no matter. Let it go. Theres few or none will entertain it.
dialogs.translated: That won't matter. Let it fly off. No one will take it in.

dialogs.original: What if it come to thee again?
dialogs.translated: What if it comes back to you?

dialogs.original: Ill not meddle with it. It makes a man a coward: a mancannot steal but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbors wife but it detects him.   'Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a mans bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles.   It made me once restore a purse of gold that by chance I found. It beggars any man that keeps it.   It is turned out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to live well endeavors to trust to himself and live without it.
dialogs.translated: I won't bother with it. A conscience makes a man a coward. A man can't steal without it accusing him; he can't swear without it restraining him; he can't sleep with his neighbor's wife without it exposing him. It's a blushing, shamefaced spirit that betrays a man's heart. It fills him with obstacles. It once made me return a purse full of gold that I found. A conscience can turn any man into a beggar. It's been thrown out of towns and cities like a dangerous enemy. Any man who wants to live well should trust only himself, and live without his conscience.

dialogs.original: Zounds, tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not tokill the duke.
dialogs.translated: My God, now it's even at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.

dialogs.original: Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not. He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.
dialogs.translated: Ignore your conscience, and think about the devil instead. He might flatter you, but he won't make you sad.

dialogs.original: I am strong-framed. He cannot prevail with me.
dialogs.translated: I'm strong-willed. My conscience won't overcome me.

dialogs.original: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?
dialogs.translated: Spoken like a brave man who values his reputation. Come, shall we get to work?

dialogs.original: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.
dialogs.translated: Hit him on the head with the hilt of your sword, and then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.

dialogs.original: O excellent device and make a sop of him.
dialogs.translated: Oh, what an excellent planwe'll make him a sponge for the wine.

dialogs.original: Soft, he wakes.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, he's waking up.

dialogs.original: Strike!
dialogs.translated: Strike!

dialogs.original: No, well reason with him.
dialogs.translated: No, we'll talk to him first.

dialogs.original: Where art thou, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.
dialogs.translated: Where are you, jailer? Give me a cup of wine.

dialogs.original: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
dialogs.translated: You'll have plenty of wine soon enough, my lord.

dialogs.original: In Gods name, what art thou?
dialogs.translated: In God's name, who are you?

dialogs.original: A man, as you are.
dialogs.translated: A man, like you are.

dialogs.original: But not, as I am, royal.
dialogs.translated: But not a royal man, as I am.

dialogs.original: Nor you, as we are, loyal.
dialogs.translated: And you're not a loyal man, as we are.

dialogs.original: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
dialogs.translated: You speak with authority, but you look like a common man.

dialogs.original: My voice is now the kings, my looks mine own.
dialogs.translated: I'm speaking for the kingmy looks are my own.

dialogs.original: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! Your eyes do menace me. Why look you pale?Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?
dialogs.translated: Your words are so dark and threatening! Your eyes menace me. Why do you look so pale? Who sent you here? Why have you come?

dialogs.original: To, to, to
dialogs.translated: To, to, to

dialogs.original: To murder me?
dialogs.translated: To murder me?

dialogs.original: Ay, ay.
dialogs.translated: Yes, yes.

dialogs.original: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it. Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?
dialogs.translated: You hardly have the heart to tell me, so you must not have the heart to do it. Besides, my friends, have I offended you?

dialogs.original: Offended us you have not, but the king.
dialogs.translated: You haven't offended usyou offended the king.

dialogs.original: I shall be reconciled to him again.
dialogs.translated: He and I will be reconciled again.

dialogs.original: Never, my lord. Therefore prepare to die.
dialogs.translated: Never, my lord. So prepare to die.

dialogs.original: Are you drawn forth among a world of men    To slay the innocent? What is my offense?    Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?    What lawful quest have given their verdict up    Unto the frowning judge?   Or who pronounced    The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death    Before I be convict by course of law?    To threaten me with death is most unlawful.    I charge you, as you hope to have redemption,    By Christs dear blood shed for our grievous sins,    That you depart, and lay no hands on me.   The deed you undertake is damnable.
dialogs.translated: Have you been chosen specially, just to kill the innocent? What is my offense? Where is the evidence against me? What jury has sentenced me in front of a frowning judge? Or who has pronounced this death sentence on me before I could be convicted by a court of law? To threaten me with death is wrong. If you hope to be saved by Christ's dear bloodwhich was shed for our sinsthen I tell you to leave now without touching me. The deed you plan to do is punishable with damnation.

dialogs.original: What we will do, we do upon command.
dialogs.translated: What we do, we do because we were commanded to.

dialogs.original: And he that hath commanded is our king.
dialogs.translated: And the one who has commanded us is our king.

dialogs.original: Erroneous vassals, the great King of kings    Hath in the tables of His law commanded    That thou shalt do no murder.   Will thou then    Spurn at His edict and fulfill a mans?    Take heed, for He holds vengeance in His hand    To hurl upon their heads that break His law.
dialogs.translated: You misguided subjects, the great King of KingsGodhas said in his Ten Commandments that "you shall not murder." Will you then disobey God's commandment just to obey a man's? Beware, for God holds vengeance in his hand, waiting to smite those who break his laws.

dialogs.original: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee    For false forswearing and for murder too.    Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight    In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
dialogs.translated: And he will smite you with that same vengeance for breaking your oaths, and for murder too. You swore a holy oath to fight for the house of Lancaster.

dialogs.original: And, like a traitor to the name of God,Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade Unrippedst the bowels of thy sovereigns son.
dialogs.translated: Andlike a traitor to the name of Godyou broke that vow, and with your treacherous sword you ripped open the chest of your king, Henry's, son Edward.

dialogs.original: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
dialogs.translated: Whom you were sworn to cherish and defend.

dialogs.original: How canst thou urge Gods dreadful law to usWhen thou hast broke it in such dear degree?
dialogs.translated: How can you preach about God's laws to us when you have broken them to such an extreme degree?

dialogs.original: Alas! For whose sake did I that ill deed?    For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.    He sends you not to murder me for this,    For in that sin he is as deep as I.    If God will be avengèd for this deed,    O, know you yet He doth it publicly!    Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm;    He needs no indirect or lawless course    To cut off those that have offended Him.
dialogs.translated: Alas! But for whose sake did I do that terrible deed? For my brother Edward, for his sake. He can't be sending you to murder me for the prince's deathbecause in that, he is just as guilty as I am. If God intends to punish me for this deed, oh, you know that he will do it publicly! God has no need for indirect or illegal methods of killing those who have offended him.

dialogs.original: Who made thee then a bloody ministerWhen gallant-springing, brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?
dialogs.translated: Who provoked you to kill that brave and lively youth, Prince Edward?

dialogs.original: My brothers love, the devil, and my rage.
dialogs.translated: My brother's love; the devil; and my rage.

dialogs.original: Thy brothers love, our duty, and thy faultsProvoke us hither now to slaughter thee.
dialogs.translated: Well, your brother's love; our duty; and your own crimes now provoke us to kill you.

dialogs.original: If you do love my brother, hate not me.    I am his brother, and I love him well.    If you are hired for meed, go back again,    And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,    Who shall reward you better for my life    Than Edward will for tidings of my death.
dialogs.translated: If you really love my brother Richard, then don't hate me. I am his brother, and I love him very much. If you're hired to do this for money, then go back again and talk to my brother the Duke of Gloucester. He will reward you better for sparing my life than King Edward will for news of my death.

dialogs.original: You are deceived. Your brother Gloucester hates you.
dialogs.translated: You are deceived. Your brother Richard hates you.

dialogs.original: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.Go you to him from me.
dialogs.translated: Oh, no, he loves me and cherishes me. Go to him from me.

dialogs.original: Ay, so we will.
dialogs.translated: Yes, so we will.

dialogs.original: Tell him, when that our princely father York    Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,    And charged us from his soul to love each other,    He little thought of this divided friendship.    Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
dialogs.translated: Tell him that when our princely father, the Duke of York, blessed his three sons and commanded us to love each other, he never imagined that our friendship would end up divided like this. Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.

dialogs.original: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.
dialogs.translated: Yes, he'll weep stones, as he taught us to do.

dialogs.original: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.
dialogs.translated: Oh, do not slander him, for he is a kind man.

dialogs.original: As snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself.'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.
dialogs.translated: As kind as snow during harvest time. Come, you're deceiving yourself. It's Richard who sent us here to kill you.

dialogs.original: It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune,And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobsThat he would labor my delivery.
dialogs.translated: It cannot be. He wept over my imprisonment. And he hugged me in his arms, and swore while sobbing that he would work to have me released.

dialogs.original: Why, so he doth, when he delivers youFrom this earths thralldom to the joys of heaven.
dialogs.translated: Why, that's what he didand now you'll be released from the prison of earth, to be free among the joys of heaven.

dialogs.original: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
dialogs.translated: Make your peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

dialogs.original: Have you that holy feeling in your souls    To counsel me to make my peace with God,    And art you yet to your own souls so blind    That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?    O sirs, consider: they that set you on    To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
dialogs.translated: You have enough holy feeling in your souls to advise me to make my peace with God. But you're still willing to disobey God by murdering me? Oh, sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.

dialogs.original: [to FIRST MURDERER]  What shall we do?
dialogs.translated: [To the FIRST MURDERER] What should we do?

dialogs.original: Relent, and save your souls.    Which of youif you were a prince's son    Being pent from liberty, as I am now    If two such murderers as yourselves came to you,    Would you not entreat for life?   Ay, you would beg,    Were you in my distress.
dialogs.translated: Give up this attempt, and save your souls. Which of you, if you were in my positiona prince's son in prison, and two murderers like yourselves came to youwouldn't beg for your life? Yes, you would beg, if you were in my situation.

dialogs.original: Relent? No. 'Tis cowardly and womanish.
dialogs.translated: Give up? No. That's cowardly and womanish.

dialogs.original: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.     [to SECOND MURDERER]     My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks.    O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,    Come thou on my side and entreat for me.    A begging prince what beggar pities not?
dialogs.translated: But to not give up, and murder me, is beastly, savage, and devilish.

dialogs.original: Look behind you, my lord.
dialogs.translated: Look behind you, my lord.

dialogs.original: Take that, and that.  [stabs CLARENCE]  If all this will not do,Ill drown you in the malmsey butt within.
dialogs.translated: Take that, and that. [He stabs CLARENCE] If all this won't do the job, then I'll drown you in that wine barrel.

dialogs.original: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched. How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my handsOf this most grievous murder.
dialogs.translated: A bloody deed, and desperately done. I wish I could wash my hands of this sad murder, as Pontius Pilate did.

dialogs.original: How now? What meanst thou, that thou helpst me not?By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.
dialogs.translated: What's going on? What's wrong with you, that you didn't help me? By God, the duke will hear about how you've neglected your duty.

dialogs.original: I would he knew that I had saved his brother. Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say,For I repent me that the duke is slain.
dialogs.translated: I wish he could hear that I had saved his brother. You take the reward, and tell him what I've said. I'm sorry that the Duke of Clarence has been killed.

dialogs.original: So do not I. Go, coward as thou art.    Well, Ill go hide the body in some hole    Till that the duke give order for his burial.    And when I have my meed, I will away,    For this will out, and then I must not stay.
dialogs.translated: I'm not sorry. Go, coward that you are. Well, I'll go hide the body in some hole until the Duke of Gloucester gives orders for its burial. And when I have my reward, I'll flee. For this murder will be found out, and I must not be around then.
